item.title: IMC - India meets Classic presents ... StudioTalk No. 1 (ENG / IMC OnAir Special Feature)
item.author: Lothar J.R. Maier (promotion initiative IMC - India meets Classic)
item.description:
Original English Version ...http://home.arcor.de/imc-studiotalk/radio/01-10052006/

IMC OnAir - India meets Classic presents its special feature StudioTalk "Music follows Behaviour!" - www.IMCRadio.Net ...

From Calcutta, India the Mandoline player Sugato Bhaduri makes a stop over in Hamburg for a studio talk about Indian Classical Music ...

+++++++++++++++++++++++

item.title: StudioTALK No. 1 (part 1 of 3) - Music follows Behaviour (special feature)
item.author: Lothar J.R. Maier (promotion initiative IMC - India meets Classic)
item.description:
The promotion initiative IMC India meets Classic presents "StudioTalk No. 1 - Music follows Behaviour!"

STUDIOTALK is the new special feature of the promotion initiative IMC - India meets Classic, beside its monthly broadcasting show "RAGA CDs of the month" (via radio + podcasting). The STUDIOTALK No. 1 is under the headline "Music follows Behaviour!".

The mandolin is an instrument of the Western world, which arrests a growing attention for Indian Classical Music during the last two decades, especially for the instrumental interpretation of ragas. Ragas are the frame work of the Indian Classical Music. They describe the emotional expression and define the material of notes.

Within an interview in the Hamburg studio of IMC the Indian music maestro and mandolin player Shri Sugato Bhaduri, Kolkatta is being presented during a stop over of his European Concert Tour in May 2006.

item.title: StudioTALK No. 1 (part 2 of 3) - Music follows Behaviour (special feature)
item.author: Lothar J.R. Maier (promotion initiative IMC - India meets Classic)
item.description:
At the age of 32 S. Bhaduri belongs to the disciple of younger Indian music talents like the vocalist Shounak Abhisheki, son of Pandit Jitendra Abhisheki, flautist Rupak Kulkarni, disciple of flute maestro Pandit Hariprasad Chourasia, the sitar player Niladri Kumar, son of Pandit Kartick Kumar, Anoushka Shankar, also Sitar player as the daughter of India's most famous music export Pandit Ravi Shankar, and the two sons of Ustad Amjad Ali Khan on the Sarode, Ayaan Ali Khan, born in 1979 and Amaan Ali Khan, 29 years old or Abhijit Pohankar, a disciple of santoor legend Pandit ShivKumar Sharma, deftly plays his ragas on the keyboad.

Padmashri U. Shrinivas is the first exponent and pioneer of Carnatic music on the mandoline, master of the 5-stringed Indian mandolin. Shrinivas was born in 1969, received his initiation into music from his father Sri Satyanarayana and started playing mandolin at the age of six. He was trained under the guidance Sri Rudraraju Subbaraju, a vocalist. Still Shrinivas is settled in Chennai, formerly Madras in Southern India. Following public recognition and acceptance in December 1981 during the Madras Musical Festival for the Indian Fine Arts Society, Shrinivas spent many years touring the world extensively. His concerts were higly acclaimed and he was showered with many prestigious awards. At the West Berlin Jazz Festival in 1983, he was privileged to give a repeat performance of his mandolin, which was telecast live by German TV. Shrinivas has also trained his brother U. Rajesh to play the mandolin. This mandolin duet promises to be a rare treat in our nower times.

Another up-and-coming artist on the Mandolin beside Sugato Bhaduri is Snehasish Mozumder, who also lives in Kolkatta. Evocative ragas and Indian Folc Music and Mozumder's dark yet mellow sound are documented on his debut album "Mandolin Dreams - Indian Mandolin & Tabla", published by the music label Latitudes.

item.title: IMC - India meets Classic praesentiert ... StudioTalk Nr. 1 (DE / IMC OnAir Special Feature)
item.author: Lothar J.R. Maier (Foerderinitiative IMC - India meets Classic)
item.description:
... Deutschfassung (Rueck-Uebersetzung) ab Sendung 09/2006, Sendeplan siehe www.imcradio.net .

IMC OnAir - India meets Classic praesentiert das Special Feature StudioTalk Musik fogt dem Bewusstsein! - www.IMCRadio.Net ...

Aus Kalkutta (Indien) ist der Mandolinspieler Sugato Bhaduri fuer ein StudioTalk zur indisch klassischen Musik zu Gast in Hamburg bei IMC  OnAir ... S. Bhaduri befindet sich z.Z. auf Konzerttournee durch Europa.

++++++++++++++++++++++++

item.title: SpecialFeature StudioTALK Nr. 1 (Teil 1 von 3) - Musik folgt dem Bewusstsein
item.author: Lothar J.R. Maier (Foerderinitiative IMC - India meets Classic)
item.description: Ab 26/06/2006 gibt's bei "IMC OnAir" die erste Ausgabe des neuen SpecialFeatures "STUDIOTALK". Es wird in loser Folge neben den monatlichen Sendeterminen via Radio + PodCasting ausgestrahlt.

item.title: SpecialFeature StudioTALK Nr. 1 (Teil 2 von 3) - Musik folgt dem Bewusstsein
item.author: Lothar J.R. Maier (Foerderinitiative IMC - India meets Classic)
item.description:
Mit dem Format "STUDIOTALK bietet IMC OnAir dem interessierten Hoerer exklusive Themengespraeche aus der Welt zur indisch klassischen Musik ! - Mit STUDIOTALK haben indische Musikmeister, Musikwissenschaftler, Event-Organisatoren u.a. die Chance, sich dem europaeischen/internationalen Hoerer in einem direkten Dialog zu praesentieren.

STUDIOTALK ist kein klassisches Interview von 5-10 Minuten "SmallTalk" zu Konzerttourneen, CD/DVD-Neuerscheinungen o.ae. Vielmehr bietet IMC OnAir mit einer aufwendigen Sendeplanung und detaillierten Vorrecherchen den Rahmen fuer spezielle Themenaspekte, die einen Beitrag zu einem tiefergehenden Verstaendnis (aus europaeischer Sicht) fuer die indisch klassische Musik leisten werden.

item.title: SpecialFeature StudioTALK Nr. 1 (Teil 3 von 3) - Musik folgt dem Bewusstsein
item.author: Lothar J.R. Maier (Foerderinitiative IMC - India meets Classic)
item.description: Fuer STUDIOTALK No. 1 war der indische Musikmeister Shri Sugato Bhaduri (Mandoline), Kalkutta waehrend seiner EuropaTournee 2006 im Hamburg-Studio zu Gast bei IMC - India meets Classic ... S. Bhaduri gehoert als Interpret der indisch klassischen Musik zu dem hoffnungsvollen Musikernachwuchs Indiens.
